title: Tuesday, 5th February 2019
bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:10am

VV75 morning
DJ morning

Also, hello. This is Markets Live, FT Alpasregfuoadrgiosdgf.

Curious I see HMV have been bought

Grouchmonkey Top of the morning
BE11:11am

And apologies for the slightly late start, which was due to me being trained on how to use a phone headset thing. Because we don't have phones any more.

11:12 am

BE11:12am

Anyway.

DJ @BE 1) Put in ear. 2) Take call?

And let's get BP out of the way.

11:14 am
BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 544.60, up 24.5 (+4.71%), High: 545.60, Low: 536.50, Volume: 17.04m
FJ @Flaneur: Doesn't matter. Amazon will eat everyone in the end.
Soundbuy Morning
BE11:16am

Q4 beats by miles. It's the kind of beat that suggests not that BP outperformed expectations but that the herd of analysts got it quite seriously wrong.

Excel Developer If regime change in Venezuela and the new guy gets US blessing won;t he export more oil, isn't regime change bearish for crude.
BE11:16am

Upstream, downstream and development all substantially ahead.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Here's Caz's summary:

BE11:17am

BP reported clean 4Q earnings $3,477m, 32% ahead of consensus $2,630m
and CFFO ex-WC $8.6bn vs. JPMe $6.1bn. Key highlights; 1) Strong beat led by downstream: A robust downstream result ($2.2bn vs. cons. $1.5bn) came in flat q/q as strong marketing (parachute effect vs. falling oil) and refining performance mitigated lower headline refining margins and (5-6 weeks) Whiting maintenance. Gas trading was a supportive feature within Upstream; 2) Gearing and disposals: ND/CE moved through the top end of BP's 20-30% range at 30.3% on BHP completion. A restated $10bn disposal target over the next two years aims to return gearing to mid-range by 2020; 3) Outlook – key points: Capex remains $15bn-17bn pa (FY18 came at the low end, $15.1bn) and Macondo outflows are reiterated at c.$2bn 2019. Underlying 2019 production is expected higher y/y on continued project delivery, with 1Q reported volumes expected flat on 4Q; in downstream BP expects significantly lower 1Q refining margins and narrower NAM L/H spreads; 4) Working cap: Was broadly flat q/q excluding the seasonal German mineral tax outflow (c.$1.5bn) despite lower oil prices. We expect this reflects active WC management including using wider NAM L-H spreads to build heavy oil stocks against Whiting downtime; 5) Dividend: Unchanged at $10.25c.

BE11:17am

4Q reported CFFO $6.8bn, add back post-tax Macondo outflow $273mn gives headline CFFO $7.1bn. We then add an underlying working cap loss $1.4bn to get underlying CFFO $8.6bn; 4Q organic capex $4.4bn vs. $3.7bn last quarter implies clean FCF of $4.2bn for the quarter, which compares to cash dividends of $1.7bn (plus a 4Q18 issuance worth a further $322m). BP’s cash breakeven (post total dividends) in 4Q18 is $28/bbl and $46/bbl for FY18.

FATDAZ @excel with you on that
11:18 am
BE11:18am

$28 a barrel breakeven?!?

DRichi @Excel- it will take a looong time to ramp up production in Venezuela. The oil is there, but the infrastructure less so these days
BE11:18am

We reiterate our fundamental OW and continue to model a best in class fall in cash breakevens ($33/bbl in 2020 vs. sector average of $44/bbl). While BP sits in the middle of the range on cash return (buyback and dividend as a percentage of market cap) as gearing falls back into the 20-30% range we believe there is scope to launch a buyback and/or increase the dividend in 2019, subject to delivery of divestments (now targeted at $10bn over two years).

Flaneur @fatdaz - I was minded to think that the 'crisis' was designed to keep the oil price *up* and support those plaid-shirt fracking jobs in the mid west...
BE11:20am

And that's probably all the comment you need on BP. Dividend 2x covered is beginning to look overly cautious.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

As for Venezuela ......

FATDAZ Re oil looking at CME settlements Brent contracts in spring 2022 trade a almost a couple of bucks below the front month so i guess you could argue they are discounting some increased supply
BE11:21am

... let's worry about the sanctions before worrying about the new guy turning on the taps.

FATDAZ @flanneur sure there is a lot of truth in that
Excel Developer @Daz: is that an oil futures curve? is it on a website? link?
BE11:22am

As per Barclays .....

Excel Developer ah https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/crude-oil/brent-crude-oil.html
11:22 am
BE11:23am

The newly issued General Licenses will inhibit trade withVenezuela, as the Venezuelan authorities would not have an incentive to maintain shipments to the US if they cannot receive the payment. This would amount to a significant oil supply disruption for the US Gulf Coast refining system. Though imports have declined with higher shale output, almost all of the 2.6 mb/d of crude these refineries imported in 2018 was medium and heavy crude. Of the 1.7 mb/d of the heavy crude that these refineries imported around 30% comes from Venezuela.

FATDAZ @Flanneur I found a plaid shirt with quilted inner that i had forgotten about and it came in v handy in last weeks cold spell
FATDAZ @excel yes https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/crude-oil/brent-crude-oil.html though doesnt seem to be updating fully at the mo
BE11:24am

From an oil market perspective, our commodity team lay outthree main scenarios –the decline in output by 2Q19 ranges from as high as 700kb/d in the continuity scenario to as low as 350kb/d in their new base case ..... Depending on the political outcome, the price effects of the recent changes introduce more medium-term uncertainty than short term, as the production outcomes, even by 2021, could vary by over 1mb/d

BE11:25am

From our equity perspective, the US sanctions on Venezuelahave led to more questions from investors around the impact on Repsol. The grouphas the largest exposure to Venezuela with 24% of proved reserves (2017) booked in the region. The impact is much lower in terms of production at less than 10% and lower still in terms of FCF, which we estimate is essentially net neutral to the group. The secondary effect is that it is likely to further tighten the light-heavy spreads in crude that are so important to refining profitability. In addition, this puts the treatment of trade receivables into question. Repsol has ~EUR800m of net trade receivables outstanding at the end of 3Q18 from Venezuela. Last year, the group agreed with PdVSA on a crude-for-debt deal, where PdVSA would ship crude oil directly to Repsol as repayment for debt. Repsol received several cargoes in 2H18 but the continuity of this going forward is uncertain. We have seen in the press(FT, 31stJanuary 2019) that Repsol took 53kb/d Venezuela oil in the past three months with the majority processed at its Cartagena and Bilbao refineries. If this crude-for-debt deal stops, this could impact the sourcing of heavy crude and valuation of receivables.

Excel Developer @Bryce : I think I read somewhere that there are shipments already in process and that they will take 3 months to drop out so any supply impact on oil will hit May (re Investing.com)
Shinshin @BE but sanctions could go overnight. Regme change on Sunday, sanctions dropped Monday, halliburton jet lands Caracas Tuesday.
FATDAZ @BE have seen several bullish comments on commodities from bank strategists in recent weeks odd really given downturn in global growth not odd I guess if you think this is the bottom
11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@Shinshin: that's true. It's just that my brain struggles to put these outcomes and probabilities into a trading strategy for Brent 2022-delivery futures.)

BE11:29am

What else can we do in our valuable time together?

11:29 am

Drugs? There's always drugs.

Grouchmonkey Speaking of groundhog day, another statement from Indivior, I note.
Indivior PLC (INDV:LSE): Last: 100.01, down 13.14 (-11.62%), High: 104.00, Low: 84.42, Volume: 2.23m
Excel Developer Let's do drugs.
BE11:30am

Unsurprisingly, the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has kicked out Indivior's request to reconsider its ruling......

11:30 am
BE11:30am

.... to lift the injunction on Dr Reddy's (and by extrapolation everyone else) from launching generic Suboxone.

BE11:31am

Indivior makes the usual noises about trying again, including to the Supreme Court

hornblower if there isn't much to cover what does the Jeffries note on Greencore say, up 8% on the back
VV75 no chance the supreme court will take the case

... but even allowing for their drowning-man strategy, we get generic Suboxone on the market from February 11.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And what's important is that we get loads of generic Suboxone.

GBKrona @hornblower - lots of big funds buying into GNC big time last few days
BE11:33am

Dr Reddy’s, Alvogen and Mylan all appear ready to launch.

BE11:34am

More important to the price than last night's news, arguably, was Indivior settling with Alvogen and cancelling a Preliminary Injunction hearing

Soundbuy Greencore - Susquehanna International appearing with 6.5% holding
Grouchmonkey What's this about a rescue deal for interserve?
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Which had been due to roll on Thursday, and folding feels like a tacit surrender from Indivior.

BE11:35am

Here's Credit Suisse.

BE11:36am

The market has been expecting some period of low competition for Dr. Reddy's. However, today's agreement does away with the lead time associated with the PI hearing against Alvogen and paves the way for immediate entry as soon as a favourable ruling is entered in favour of Dr. Reddy’s. This intensifies competition in Suboxone, which now should be at least a four generic market at formation: Mylan, Alvogen, AG (Sandoz) and Dr. Reddy’s.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Added to that list you have Par. which has settled with Indivior but is awaiting FDA approval.

BE11:37am

Also, have some Jefferies.

BE11:38am

INDV has announced that the US Court of Appeals has denied its request for a rehearing to reconsider its decision to lift the injunction of DRRD gSuboxone launch, paving the way for a crowded launch on Feb 11, before JEFe March 1. '19E R&D and SG&A outlook is also higher than JEFe; hence we expect guidance below cons at FY Results on Feb 14. We look for further progress on Sublocade at the results which has now become more critical to the business.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Stifel.

BE11:38am

Expecting multiple generic versions and 80% erosion of US sales - already in our
model. As well as DRL resuming its generic launch, Indivior also assumes that Alvogen
will launch its generic in the US once the CAFC issues the mandate and the PI is
removed. Alvogen received FDA approval for its generic version on 24 January 2019.
There is also a chance that the entrance of generics allows Mylan to launch its generic
version, which previously was prevented from launching until 2023 under terms of a
patent litigation settlement between Mylan and Indivior, although the exact terms have
never been disclosed. Nevertheless, we had already assumed 80% generic erosion of
Suboxone US sales in 2019, declining to $150m from an estimated $750m in 2018. Our
revenue forecasts are therefore unchanged.
Expansion of contingency plans, further cuts to the cost base. Indivior has already
been implementing its contingency and cost restructuring plans for some time (starting in
July 2018), which has so far delivered a) $235m reduction in debt to end-2018 at $243m;
b) cash conservation resulting in a cash balance of $920m at end-2018; and c) significant
headcount reductions. With the expected launch of generics, Indivior plans to launch is
own authorised generic version (via Sandoz) to capture some share of the generic market
(expects tens of $ millions net revenue), and seek further further cost savings, such
as delaying and/or cancelling R&D projects. As such, Indivior expects combined opex
(R&D + SG&A) in FY 2019 to be $440m to $460m. We have lowered our opex forecasts
accordingly, which indicates the company could now be break-even at the operating level
for 2019 vs our prior expectations for a $58m operating loss. As ever, the key remains
Sublocade and we believe the current share price indicates much more modest peak
sales potential ($150-200m) than our expectations.

BE11:38am

And Numis.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

● New cost guidance raises questions: Indivior has maintained the $250m cash
backstop, but expects $440m - $460m of S,G&A and R&D in FY19, which would be just
$120m less than the anticipated opex for FY18 (NSe $560m). With the cash backstop
maintained, the opex guidance would indicate far higher revenue expectations than our
consensus low $390m, or less cash outflow in other areas (working cap, settlements,
capex) and/or further divestments of non-core operations. We await further details at
the results next week.
● High risk/high reward strategy: maintaining this level of S,G&A implies a material
operating loss in FY19 on our $391m revenue forecast (c'sus $391m - $520m).
However, maintaining the sales and marketing investment could prove decisive
in the launch trajectory for Sublocade where payer budgets could become more
accommodating with significant anticipated cost reductions likely to hit the dailies.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Here's the Jefferies note in full.

BE11:49am

We resume coverage at Buy, following a period of restriction as a result of the recent tender offer. Our forecasts are unchanged down to the PBT level. Our new price target is 245p, which reflects unchanged target multiples.

Resuming coverage at Buy. We resume coverage, after a period of restriction following the recent tender offer, the completion of which was announced on 31 January.

Minimal changes to forecasts. Our forecasts are unchanged at the sales, EBIT & PBT level relative to our forecasts published prior to restriction. We make minor changes to our dividend assumptions. consequent on the final share count, which has a small impact on cashflow & net debt. Headline EPS (which is defined as continued plus discontinued ops in FY19) changes little.

PT of 245p. Our 12 month PT of 245p reflects unchanged target EV:EBITDA assumptions from our views published prior to the restriction period.

BE11:50am

Honestly, that's it. Beyond the forecast page, which you can have as well if you want.

11:58 am
Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 1,311, up 38 (+2.99%), High: 1,343, Low: 1,278, Volume: 272.91k
BE11:59am

Has had a bit of a bounce in recent days. Today's is helped by Ian Gordon at Investec.

BE12:00pm

As per our report, Clang... (23 Jan), unsurprisingly, the market took fright after an unexpected £900m hit to RWAs (1.5% off CET1) which looks likely to pull forward the next capital raise to support growth. Also, the notably weak Q4 2018 pre-impairment profit suggests (to us) an adverse mix effect and cost miss in the quarter. Be that as it may, Metro has morphed into a bank with a “normal” 1.0x 2018e tNAV rating with an abnormal growth outlook. Worth another look?

Grouchmonkey Speaking of banks, anyone know where we are on Deutsche-Commerzbank?
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

RWAs increased by £1.5bn QoQ to £8.9bn in Q4 2018. Of this, £0.6bn reflects further strong loan growth, with £0.9bn due to the identified “miscategorisation” of commercial loans. The CET1 capital ratio declines to c.13.0%, which is fine on a static basis, but is now inadequate to support further planned growth unless AIRB accreditation arrives during the next two quarters. We see that as unlikely.

BE12:01pm

Metro has options. Clearly it could radically slow loan growth ahead of AIRB to constrain capital consumption, somewhat unpalatable given its existing plan to deliver further rapid improvement in operational leverage, a function of balance sheet growth. We see the timing of migration to AIRB as critical. We think a fresh capital raise is likely and, for now, we model £300m with the H1 2019 results in July. But Metro could yet choose to “get it done”; and move as soon as 27 Feb.

BE12:01pm

We don’t yet have the all component parts of the Q4 2018 “miss”, though our assumptions include a combination of (1) continuing spread pressure in mortgages, (2) weak commercial loan growth in the quarter, hence an adverse mix impact on NIM too, (3) weak non-interest income, and (4) higher costs associated with the surge of new store openings in Nov/Dec. We expect (1) and (3) to persist, (2) to improve and (4) to ease in H1 2019e.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

By definition, a story predicated on rapid growth to drive improving operational leverage is subject to significant “forecast error”; it is higher risk. However, on 0.7x 2023e tNAV for a ROTE of 14.0% we reinstate a (more speculative) Buy rec, with a rebased TP of 1650p.

FATDAZ @BE morgan stanley wrote on UK banks yday saying that they were priced for worst Brexit outcome and therefore overdone
undefined

BE12:09pm

12:09 pm
